occurrences.line_text: Then doe your selfe, for dread of shame, forgoe
More then his loue, which thus ye seeke t'obtaine.
If I doe so, (sayd he) then liberty
To proue if better foote then horsebacke would ensew.
There then began a fearefull cruell fray
And nimbler handed, then his enemie,
Then the reproch of pride and cruelnesse.
Then forth he cald from sorrowfull dismay
Whereof she now more glad, then sory earst,
And then to his first quest he passed forth along.
As then the guize was for each gentle swayne;
Rather then let my selfe of wight be stroken,
Perdie great blame, (then said Sir Calidore)
But then aread, thou gentle chyld, wherefore
Sayd then Sir Calidore; Neither will I
Vnarm'd all was the knight, as then more meete
Then fearing any foeman there to meete:
Then as it were t'auenge his wrath on mee,
Now sure (then said Sir Calidore) and right
Then turning backe vnto that gentle boy,
To whom then thus the noble youth; May be
Then wote ye that I am a Briton borne,
The widow Queene my mother, which then hight
Faire Emiline, conceiuing then great feare
Him much more now, then earst he gan admire,
(Though none more noble then is cheualrie,)
Full glad and ioyous then young Tristram grew,
But Tristram then despoyling that dead knight
Then speaking to the Ladie, thus he sayd:
She then, like as she best could vnderstand,
Then gan Sir Calidore to ghesse streightway
His care more then her owne compassionate,
There he him found much better then he was,
He there did make, and then most carefully
Then vp he tooke her twixt his armes twaine,
Me then to be full base and euill borne,
Who sitting with his Lady then at bord,
Then Calepine, how euer inly wroth,
No more then for the stroke of strawes or bents:
Then taking vp that Recreants shield and speare,
Well then him chaunst his heauy armes to want,
And then oppressing him with vrgent paine,
Then tooke he vp betwixt his armes twaine
Much was he then encombred, ne could tell
Then North; then neither, but as fortune fell.
Then North; then neither, but as fortune fell.
Then thus began the lamentable Dame;
Sith then ye needs will know the griefe I hoord,
Well hop't he then, when this was propheside,
Then those, which haue bene dandled in the lap.
Gotten by spoyle, then purchaced aright.
Then turning to that swaine, him well he knew
Then gan the Prince, of her for to demand,
Then vp they rose, and gan them selues to dight
Of that commixtion they did then beget
Then outward salues, that may augment it more.
Aye me (sayd then Serena sighing sore)
What hope of helpe doth then for vs remaine,
Her weed she then withdrawing, did him discouer,
For greater force there needs to maintaine wrong, then right.
Said then the one of them; Where is that wight,
Deuizing of his loue more, then of daunger drad.
Then one of them aloud vnto him cryde,
Then thus said he, There is a straunger knight,
But where then is (quoth he halfe wrothfully)
T'aduize him better, then by such a traine
Then to entrap him by false treacherie:
Then letting him arise like abiect thrall,
It fortun'd then, that when the roules were red,
Then found he many missing of his crew,
Rather then once his burden to sustaine:
Then vp he made him rise, and forward fare,
Was much more grieuous, then the others blowes:
Vnder that villaines club, then surely thought
The Prince assented, and then he streight way
No more then lightening from the lofty sky.
For more on him doth then him selfe depend;
Then bursting forth in teares, which gushed fast
Her tongue to her restord, then thus she sayd;
Certes (sayd then the Prince) the God is iust,
Then suffred he Disdaine vp to arise,
Then turning backe vnto that captiue thrall,
And let him rise. Then thus the Prince gan say;
Then looking round about, and seeing nought,
Then he was tride vnto his Lady bright:
Then gan they to deuize what course to take:
And then her eate attonce; or many meales to make.
Then when she wakt, they all gaue one consent,
The Damzell wakes, then all attonce vpstart,
Benumbes her cheekes: Then out aloud she cries,
Then gan the bagpypes and the hornes to shrill,
Sir Calepine by chaunce, more then by choyce,
Then to the rest his wrathfull hand he bends,
And then to question of her present woe;
To finish then, for other present hast.
Then one of them him seeing so to sweat,
Higher then all the rest, and round about
Then came to them a good old aged syre,
Then all the rest about her rose likewise,
To lodge, then in the saluage fields to rome.
Surely my sonne (then answer'd he againe)
If happie, then it is in this intent,
For further fortune then I would inquire.
And this sweet peace, whose lacke did then appeare.
In vaine (said then old Meliboe) doe men
Since then in each mans self (said Calidore)
Then all that he could doe, or euer deuize:
That who had seene him then, would haue bethought
That she did loue a stranger swayne then him more dere.
They fell to daunce: then did they all agree,
Then Coridon woxe frollicke, that earst seemed dead.
Then was the oaken crowne by Pastorell
Rather then hunt still after shadowes vaine
Not I so happy, answerd then that swaine,
Right sory I, (saide then Sir Calidore,)
Then wote thou shepheard, whatsoeuer thou bee,
That good should from vs goe, then come in greater store.
His life he steemed dearer then his frend.
Amongst the rest, the which they then did pray,
Liker to heauen, then mortall wretchednesse.
That further, then she willing was, he prest;
Then forth the good old Meliboe was brought,
But then the Captaine fraught with more displeasure,
Who minding more her safety then himselfe,
Then all their helpes they busily applyde,
Ah well away (sayd he then sighing sore)
Die? out alas! then Calidore did cry:
He thus began: Where shall I then commence
Then here to see all desolate and wast,
Then for to die with her, and his liues threed to breake.
The which for want of heards themselues then kept.
Then backe returning to his dearest deare,
The fayrest Ladie then of all that liuing were.
Then all the stormes of fortunes former yre
Whereof her name ye then to her did giue.
Then her embracing twixt her armes twaine,
Straunge bands, whose like till then he neuer bore,
Ne euer any durst till then impose,
To mortall men, then he had done before;
More then my former writs, all were they clearest
Soone as she parted thence, the fearefull twaine,
Thence to the hall, which was on euery side
He standes amazed, how he thence should fade.
Thence turning backe in silence soft they stole,
Which hauing seene, from thence arose away
Departed thence, albe his woundes wide
Good cause he had to hasten thence away;
Thence lead her forth, about her dauncing round,
How with that pensiue Maid he best might thence arise.
Therewith the knight thence marched forth in hast,
The euer-burning lamps from thence it braught,
So vp he rose, and thence amounted streight.
That drops of bloud thence like a well did play;
From thence to heauen she teacheth him the ready path.
The faultie soules from thence brought to his heauenly bowre.
Thence forward by that painfull way they pas,
From thence, far off he vnto him did shew
From thence a Faerie thee vnweeting reft,
Thence she thee brought into this Faerie lond,
He thence departing gaue for his paines hyre.
Till merry wind and weather call her thence away.
From thence it comes, that this babes bloudy hand
Thence forth in battell neuer sword to beare,
The weary soule from thence it would discharge;
Strikes in the stocke, ne thence can be rel[e]ast,
Of his departure thence; for of her ioy
That she well pleased was thence to amoue him farre.
Thence forward he him led, and shortly brought
And thence him forward led, him further to entise.
Yet forcing it to faine, him forth thence led
Haue cleft his head in twaine, and life thence dispossest.
Red as the Rose, thence gushed grieuously;
Vtterers of secrets he from thence debard,
Thence she them brought into a stately Hall,
And one great chimney, whose long tonnell thence,
Till by a conduit pipe it thence were brought:
Thence backe againe faire Alma led them right,
Till that great Ladie thence away them sought,
Thence brought th[m] to the second roome, whose wals
But Alma thence the[m] led to th'hindmost roome of three.
For all so soone, as Guyon thence was gon
That the disdainfull soule he thence dispatcht,
Thence passing forth, they shortly do arriue,
With shady Laurell trees, thence to defend
And counseld well, him forward thence did draw.
Tryde all her arts, & all her sleights, thence out to wrest.
Thence they were brought to that great Ladies vew,
And thence pourd into men, which men call Loue;
From thence, him firmely bound with faithfull band,
To finde some issue thence, till that at last
Into that forest farre they thence him led,
But Venus hers thence farre away conuayd,
All things from thence doe their first being fetch,
In secret wize her selfe thence to withdraw,
Thence backe returning to the former land,
And with them sayling thence, to th'Isle of Paros came.
His sonne Iulus did from thence depart,
From thence he threw himselfe dispiteously,
Ne may by liuing meanes be thence relest:
Deliuer her fro thence, or with her for you dy.
Thence forth descending to that perlous Porch,
Thence to depart for further aide t'enquire:
By thousand furies, and from thence out throwen
Departed thence with full contended mynd;
Thence streames of purple bloud issuing rife,
Thence to depart with glee and gladsome chere.
And brought with her fro[m] thence that goodly belt away.
But secretly from thence that night her bore away.
That she was gone, departed thence with speed,
And oft in wrath he thence againe vprose;
So sorely he her strooke, that thence it glaunst
Her ventayle shard away, and thence forth glaunst
My Amoret, sith you her freed fro thence,
They tooke their steeds, and forward thence did pas
Fit time for him thence to depart it found,
Or hard misfortune she was thence conuayd,
Came to the caue, and rolling thence the stone,
A streame of coleblacke bloud thence gusht amaine,
Thence forth she past into his dreadfull den,
Thence she them brought toward the place, where late
To know, what Virgin did them thence vnbind;
Soone as they thence departed were afore,
Yet seeing not how thence he mote remoue,
Thence she commaunded me to prison new;
Thence forth were brought to him aboue a score
Thence forth I passed to the second gate,
Both gifts of God not gotten but from thence,
In presence of them all forth led her thence:
Thus safely with my loue I thence did wend.
And meeting Plim, to Plimmouth thence declines:
Thence doth by Huntingdon and Cambridge flit;
Ne thence the Irishe Riuers absent were:
These three faire sons, which being the[n]ce forth powrd
Then did he cast to steale her thence away,
Yet without ship or bote her thence to row,
He wist not how her thence away to bere;
That his departure thence should be so short,
And thence Apollo King of Leaches brought.
To wend with her. So thence him farre she brought
That lim he could not wag. Thence he him lad,
He tooke it vp, and thence with him did beare,
Vnder an heape of gold. Thence he her drew
But he the right from thence did thrust away,
And now they lead him thence, of all forsaken,
Which was from thence not past a mile or tway:
So forth into the field she marched thence,
Bereaue it thence: such blot his honour blemish should.
And Artegall thence frees.
Was thence by them into the Temple led;
Thence forth vnto the Idoll they her brought,
She parted thence, her anguish to appease.
With her, to see her Ladie thence no farre away.
A straunge aduenture, which not farre thence lay;
Thence forth they passed with that gentle Mayd,
From thence pour'd down on men, by influence of grace.
Farre thence from forrein land, where they did dwell,
So thence he wished her with him to wend,
And thence vnto the castle marched right,
That naught may boot to banishe them from thence:
Yet rescue her thence by no meanes I may:
That the gore bloud thence gushing grieuously,
Sir Calidore thence trauelled not long,
Thence passing forth, into the hall he came,
A tall young man from thence not farre away,
Who ere he thence had traueild many a mile,
How thence she might conuay him to some place.
Thence they him carried to a Castle neare,
A certaine herbe from thence vnto him brought,
She bore it thence, and euer as her owne it kept.
He thence them led into his Hermitage,
Sternely did bid him quickely thence auaunt,
Thence he him brought away, and vp conuayd
Thence passing forth, not farre away he found,
So being stayd, they her from thence directed
From thence into the open fields he fled,
Of the blynd boy, ne thence could be redeemed
Ne any will had thence to moue away,
And drawing thence his speach another way,
Desired be, or thence to banish bale:
As thou vnhappy, which them thence didst chace,
That thence, he had no will away to fare,
And thence did all the spoyles and threasures take,
Thence running forth vnto her loued Lord,
He wrought, that thence all goodnesse he bereft,
From thence into the sacred Church he broke,
Thenceforth he kept her goodly company,
Thenceforth her waters waxed dull and slow,
Thenceforth me desolate he quite forsooke,
Thenceforth the suit of earthly conquest shonne,
That from thenceforth he shund the like to take,
And thenceforth were renowmd, & sought from place to place.
Ne thenceforth his approued skill, to ward,
Thenceforth she sought for helps, to cloke her crime withall.
Ne thenceforth life ne courage did appeare,
Thenceforth this Realme was into factions rent,
Thenceforth this land was tributarie made
Thenceforth Aurelius peaceably did rayne,
Thenceforth it firmely was established,
Thenceforth the feather in her loftie crest,
Thenceforth eternall vnion shall be made
Into the woods thenceforth in hast she went,
Thenceforth to her he sought to intimate
Into the same he creepes, and thenceforth there
That from thenceforth a wretched life they lad,
Like faithfull friends thenceforth to ioyne in one
Yet from thenceforth more warily he fought,
Ne thenceforth feare the thing that hethertoo
Thenceforth I sought by secret meanes to worke
Ne thenceforth euer strike in battell stroke,
Thenceforth I found more fauour at her hand,
Had it defaste; thenceforth reformd her waies,
Thenceforth they much more furiously gan fare,
And thenceforth vnto daunger opened way.
So from her parting, she thenceforth did labour
And gan thenceforth to cast affection,
Of his demeane: thenceforth not like a louer,
Thenceforth she streight into a bowre him brought,
Neuer thenceforth to nourish enmity,
Thenceforth into that Castle he her led,
Thenceforth he car'd no more, which way he strooke,
Of whom yet taking leaue, thenceforth he went
Did well auize, thenceforth with warie heed
I from thenceforth haue learn'd to loue more deare
So from thenceforth, when loue he to her made,
Thenceforth they ioy'd in happinesse together,
Thenceforth more mischiefe and more scath he wrought
And made him selfe thensample of his follie.
Thensforth I tooke Duessa for my Dame,
Thensforth from her most beastly companie
ther burnes in furious fire.
The antique rolles, which there lye hidden still,
Pointed with mortall sting. Of her there bred
Huge heapes of mudd he leaues, wherein there breed
At her wide mouth: but being there withstood
There was an holy Chappell edifyde,
Arriued there, the little house they fill,
He to his study goes, and there amiddes
His dwelling is; there Tethys his wet bed
Might there be heard: but carelesse Quiet lyes,
Lo there before his face his Lady is,
There lies he now with foule dishonour dead,
The fearefull Shepheard often there aghast
Vnder them neuer sat, ne wont there sound
There they alight, in hope themselues to hide
With goodly purposes there as they sit:
He pluckt a bough; out of whose rift there came
Nought there vnder heau'ns wilde hollownesse,
Gan shut the dore. By this arriued there
Came forth, and finding Kirkrapine there slaine,
And proudly said, Lo there the worthie meed
For vnto knight there is no greater shame,
Arriued there they passed in forth right;
There waiting long, to win the wished sight
Like euer saw. And there a noble crew
On which there sate most braue embellished
And in his bosome secretly there lay
Is there possessed of the traytour vile,
There many Minstrales maken melody,
For neuer did such brightnesse there appeare,
Descends to hell: there creature neuer past,
There was Ixion turned on a wheele,
There thirstie Tantalus hong by the chin;
There auncient Night arriuing, did alight
Aueugles sonne there in the leaches cure,
There was that great proud king of Babylon,
There also was king Croesus, that enhaunst
There also was that mightie Monarch layd
There dwell in perill of like painefull plight,
There find the virgin dolefull desolate,
And there begotten of a Lady myld,
So long in secret cabin there he held
And there abode, whilst any beast of name
There to obtaine some such redoubted knight,
There for to find a fresh vnproued knight,
There raignd a solemne silence ouer all,
There was no barre to stop, nor foe him to empeach.
There all within full rich arayd he found,
Which there were slaine, as sheepe out of the fold,
And there beside of marble stone was built
Them list no lenger there at leasure dwell,
There all my dayes he traind me vp in vertuous lore.
There him he finds all sencelesse and aghast,
And throwne about the cliffs. Arriued there,
And him beside there lay vpon the gras
He there does now enioy eternall rest
Where iustice growes, there grows eke greater grace,
There was an auntient house not farre away,
Arriued there, the dore they find fast lockt;
There fairely them receiues a gentle Squire,
That hither turnes his steps. So few there bee,
And by her side there sate a gentle paire
There when the Elfin knight arriued was,
There she awhile him stayes, him selfe to rest,
There they do finde that godly aged Sire,
And what vnknowen nation there empeopled were.
There as thou slepst in tender swadling band,
And her base Elfin brood there for thee left.
And there by force vnwonted passage find,
The percing steele there wrought a wound full wyde,
Of auncient time there was a springing well,
Where fast it stucke, ne would there out be got:
There grew a goodly tree him faire beside,
There this faire virgin wearie of her way
There eke my feeble barke a while may stay,
Therefore I ought craue pardon, till I there haue beene.
There did I find, or rather I was found
During the which there was an heauenly noise
In full content he there did long enioy,
By which there sate a knight with helme vnlast,
Faire Sir, if euer there ye trauell, shonne
To weet, what dreadfull thing was there in hand;
And were there rightfull cause of difference,
There this old Palmer shewed himselfe that day,
He that braue steed there finding ready dight,
Of what might hap. Eftsoone there stepped forth
For there their dwelling was. And when she spake,
There thou maist loue, and dearely loued bee,
There maist thou best be seene, and best maist see:
There is I know not what great difference
There wanted nought but few rites to be donne,
Yet there the steele stayd not, but inly bate
Loe there they be; to thee I yield them free.
There Atin found Cymochles soiourning,
And fast beside, there trickled softly downe
There he him found all carelesly displayd,
Atin arriuing there, when him he spide,
Yet was there not with her else any one,
Matter of merth enough, though there were none
There her small Gondelay her port did make,
And smelling sweet, but there it might be found
There by his maister left, when late he far'd
Backe to the strond retyrd, and there still stayd,
Whylest there the varlet stood, he saw from farre
Whom should he, but his owne deare Lord, there see,
Ne ought mote euer sinke downe to the bottome there.
To see Pyrrochles there so rudely rage:
Into the hollow earth, them there to hide.
All these may not suffise, there shall to thee
By that wayes side, there sate infernall Payne,
On thother side in one consort there sate,
Breake in, and spoile the treasure there in gard:
Here Sleep, there Richesse, & Hel-gate the[m] both betwext.
So soone as Mammon there arriu'd, the dore
Did shut, and from behind it forth there lept
Whose liues, it seemed, whilome there were shed,
A route of people there assembled were,
There, as in glistring glory she did sit,
There mournfull Cypresse grew in greatest store,
And planted there, did bring forth fruit of gold:
As authour of vniustice, there to let him dye.
He there beheld, too long here to be told:
Ne Mammon would there let him long remaine,
And now he has so long remained there,
A Nd is there care in heauen? and is there loue
A Nd is there care in heauen? and is there loue
There is: else much more wretched were the cace
There the good Guyon he found slumbring fast
Beside his head there sate a faire young man,
Ne was there euer noble courage seene,
It seizd in his right side, and there the dint did stay.
Fast flying, there eternall torment found,
There is no one more faire and excellent,
Came to the Ladies eare, which there did dwell,
There when they rested had a season dew,
At th'upper end there sate, yclad in red
And through the Hall there walked to and fro
There placed was a caudron wide and tall,
There added was by goodly ordinaunce,
In which there dwelt three honorable sages,
Emongst them all sate he, which wonned there,
There sate a man of ripe and perfect age,
The knights there entring, did him reuerence dew
There chaunced to the Princes hand to rize,
Th'off-spring of Elues and Faries there he fond,
Ne was there outward breach, nor grudge in hart,
She there attached, farre from all succoure;
Which hight of him Glamorgan, there him slew:
There she with them a cruell battell tride,
Succeding There abruptly it did end,
Is setled there in sure establishment;
There Alma like a virgin Queene most bright,
And planted there their huge artillery,
There follow'd fast at hand two wicked Hags,
As hurt he had not bene. Thereby there lay
And eke the fairest Alma met him there
Of her faire twins was there deliuered,
That it would tempt a man to touchen there:
But by the way, there is a great Quicksand,
For not one puffe of wind there did appeare,
There those fiue sisters had continuall trade,
And made there to abound with lauish affluence.
Which thither came: but in the Porch there sate
There the most daintie Paradise on ground,
Was there consorted in one harmonee,
There, whence that Musick seemed heard to bee,
There she had him now layd a slombering,
In captiue bandes, which there they readie found:
Then Guyon askt, what meant those beastes, which there did ly.
To make there lenger soiourne and abode;
And him beside an aged Squire there rode,
